title.narrative: Bridging the Gaps 2 - PWUD project Indonesia

description.narrative: Bridging the Gaps works with a Theory of Change approach. A Theory of Change is a description of a list of events that is expected to lead to a particular desired outcome. It is a visualization how change is believed to happen. In 2016, representatives of the PWUD community developed a specified Theory of Change that consists of short-,medium, and long term outcomes. The Theory of Change describes how we plan to realize meaningful involvement of PWUD organisations in the development of government regulations; to regain their human rights; and increased access to health insurance and health services. Through innovation and by building on previous work, we will strengthen civil society organisations’ ability to: 1. We facilitate community development - Providing paralegal services to make sure people are aware of their rights after arrest and to guarantee access to their legal rights in Indonesia; - Building the capacity of civil society on service delivery. 2. We advocate for the continuously strengthening of services and upholding human rights - Conducting research into the treatment center-system of Indonesia; - Conducting a follow-up study around crystal-meth use in Indonesia. 3. Deliver inclusive, rights-based and gender sensitive services - Developing new services for young PWUD aimed at overdose prevention and preventing switching from smoking to injecting drugs; - Piloting a project directed at crystal-meth users based on previously conducted research on sexual risk behaviours.

Mainline has a long, positive track record in Indonesia that dates back to 2006. Mainline works with different partners and under Bridging the Gaps 2 focuses on people who use chrystal-methamphetamines.

sector.narrative: Service delivery to PWID to prevent HIV infections

title.narrative: 5 Human Rights violation cases acted on

description.narrative: Human rights violation cases acted on is the number of violations documented and in the process of being acted on, instead of responded to, meaning that the cases are taken further than documentation, for example reporting, providing psychosocial and or paralegal or legal support.

title.narrative: 5 # human rights violation cases acted on

description.narrative: 5 # human rights violation cases acted on. This is the number of violations documented and in the process of being acted on, instead of ‘responded to’, meaning that the cases are taken further than documentation, for example reporting, providing psychosocial and or paralegal or legal support.

comment.narrative: Incarceration of clients were documented and after mediation, got released without legal measures been taken. Upon release, clients and family members were provided with psychosocial support.

title.narrative: 3 Law enforcement staff trained on human rights

description.narrative: Law enforcement staff trained on human rights is measured by the number of law enforcement staff trained on human rights.

title.narrative: 3 # law enforcement staff trained on human rights

description.narrative: 3 # law enforcement staff trained on human rights

comment.narrative: The trained individuals were representatives from: Police and the South Sulawesi National Narcotics Agency.

title.narrative: 4 Participation of partner organization in or organization of local national regional or global stakeholder meetings

description.narrative: Participation of partner organization in or organization of local national regional or global stakeholder meetings is measured by the number of partner organisations that participate in meetings. Meetings are defined as advocacy meetings with local national regional or global stakeholders.

title.narrative: 4 # partner organisations that participated in or organized local/national/regional/global stakeholder meetings

description.narrative: 4 # partner organisations that participated in or organized local/national/regional/global stakeholder meetings is measured by the number of partner organisations. Meetings are advocacy meetings with local/national/regional/global stakeholders.

comment.narrative: All meetings were on national and local level. It included dialogues on drug harm reduction attended by government officials, health practitioners, academics, NGOs, and community organizations. Also, members of the law enforcement were engaged to reduce stigma and discrimination in key populations at district level.

title.narrative: 1 Service provision to Key Population Members

description.narrative: Service provision to key population members measures the number of services used by key population members. This is done through 6 indicators that respectively measure the number of testing services, treatment services, PWUD specific medical harm reduction services, other health services meaning condom distribution, social services and legal support services used by key population members.

title.narrative: 1A # of KP members using testing services

description.narrative: 1A # of KP members using testing services (disaggregated by age) everything falling under voluntary counselling and testing is part of this indicator, testing for TB, STIs

comment.narrative: Bridging the Gaps uses two age groups since 2017 reporting onwards: 24 and under, and 25 and above, as agreed with MOFA. For the sex work project, the youngest age group will be 18-24 years. Mainline and partners have additional dimensions which are used to monitor reach of services: Male, female and other. No target has been set. However, our partners in Indonesia have surpassed the number of individuals reached compared to the previous years – despite the termination of contract with one of the implementing partners mid 2018. The data shown are the aggregated results of two partners.

Bridging the Gaps uses two age groups since 2017 reporting onwards: 24 and under, and 25 and above, as agreed with MOFA. For the sex work project, the youngest age group will be 18-24 years. Mainline and partners have additional dimensions which are used to monitor reach of services: Male, female and other. No target has been set. The data shown are the aggregated results of two partners

description.narrative: Trained service providers is measured through 2 indicators. The first measures the number of service providers trained. Service providers provide social services, including psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, or health NGO or public sector services. The counselling part of VCT services is excluded. They are individuals within local partner organisations within BtG that provide services, as well as from indirect service providers that receive training from BtG local partners for instance other NGO-run clinics, private clinics, state-run services, etc. The second measures the number of legal service providers trained including paralegal services
2B # legal service providers trained including paralegal services

comment.narrative: The tra trained individuals were representatives from: Legal Aid Foundation, Sawerigading University, Legal Aid Institute, PKNM Paralegal, Indonesian AIDS Coalition Focal Point Paralegal.

description.narrative: 2A # of service providers trained. This is the number of individual service providers meaning staff members, trained by alliance partner and/or by a country partner. Total # is the number of people trained by alliance partner and number of people trained by partners. Service providers provide social (including psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, NOT the counselling part of VCT services), or health(NGO or public sector) services. They are individuals within local partner organisations within BtG that provide services, as well as from indirect service providers that receive training from BtG local partners (e.g. other NGO-run clinics, private clinics, state-run services, etc).

comment.narrative: A total of 24 mental health service workers from 12 Puskesmas (municipal health department) in DKI Jakarta received capacity building in dealing with mental health challenges in relation to drug use.
The trained service providers include: Staff from multiple municipal health departments, staff from the faculty of psychiatry of a local university and those of the implementing partners.
